summary: The document details a 1972 military communication concerning a counterintelligence (CI) incident involving an individual known as 'John Dee Jay', who attempted to elicit official information from members of the 66th USA Artillery Detachment in the Federal Republic of Germany (FRG). Described as a multilingual disc jockey with pro-communist sentiments and a desire to live in the German Democratic Republic (GDR), the incident underscores Cold War-era espionage concerns. The investigation included interviews with the approached military personnel and efforts to identify 'John Dee Jay', with findings reported to higher military and investigative authorities.
key_findings: An unidentified individual, 'John Dee Jay', attempted to obtain official military information from the 66th USA Artillery Detachment in FRG.
'John Dee Jay' was multilingual and expressed pro-communist sentiments, including a desire to live in the GDR.
The incident was thoroughly investigated, with findings reported to higher authorities, highlighting ongoing efforts to identify the individual.
The document reflects Cold War-era anxieties regarding espionage and the safeguarding of military information.
